Trial_Design.evidence: We included randomized controlled trials (RCTs) conducted in preterm and term infants

Participants.evidence: preterm and term infants of a postmenstrual age up to 46 weeks and 0 days with postoperative pain

Intervention.evidence: systemic opioids were compared to 1) placebo or no intervention; 2) non‐pharmacological interventions; 3) different types of opioids; or 4) other drugs

Objective.evidence: To evaluate the benefits and harms of systemic opioid analgesics in neonates who underwent surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: Our primary outcomes were pain assessed with validated methods, all‐cause mortality during initial hospitalization, major neurodevelopmental disability, and cognitive and educational outcomes in children more than five years old

Number_Randomised.evidence: We included four RCTs enrolling 331 infants in four countries across different continents

Result_Outcome.evidence: The evidence is very uncertain about the effect of tramadol compared with placebo on all‐cause mortality during initial hospitalization (RR 0.32, 95% Confidence Interval (CI) 0.01 to 7.70; RD ‐0.03, 95% CI ‐0.10 to 0.05, 71 participants, 1 study; I² = not applicable)
